page.shortlink: api objects response object send file method
page.description: Write the content of a file to output stream
page.prototype: Context.Response.SendFile as V (Filename as C, PromptToSave as L = .F., OutputFilename as C = "__not__specified__")

argument.name: Filename
argument.description: The name of the file to written to the response's output.

argument.name: PromptToSave
argument.description: Add the Content-Disposition header to the client will prompt for save. This defaults to .F. when an OutputFilename is not specified. It defaults to .T. when an OutputFilename is specified.

argument.name: OutputFilename
argument.description: Default = "__not__specified__". The name the client should use when saving the file. This is the filename shown in the save file dialog. The user can change the filename at their discretion when they save the file on the client.

page.discussion: Context.Response.SaveFile() Write the content of a file directly to the response's output stream.

description.p: For example, the code below creates a file called "MyFile.txt" and sends it to the client where it will either be displayed in the browser or the user will be prompted to download the file.

section.example:
dim FileKey as c = "MyFile.txt" context.session.SaveDataAsFile(FileKey,"Hello World, this is a session file")
context.response.SendFile(Session.FormatFileDataURL(FileKey))

description.p: If you want to prompt the user to download the file, you can pass *[xb:.t.]* for the second parameter. When *[xb:PromptToSave]* is true, the user will be asked to save the file. You can optionally specify a default filename to show in the save dialog as the third parameter. If you do not specify an *[xb:OutputFilename]*, the server filename is used.
